name: Peperoni Pizza
description: Pizza is a beloved meal enjoyed by people all over the world. It typically consists of a round, flat base of leavened wheat-based dough topped with tomatoes, cheese, and various other ingredients such as meats, vegetables, and condiments. The dough is then baked at a high temperature, traditionally in a wood-fired oven. Eating pizza can be different each time; it can be a simple and fast snack or a fancy and special meal.

nutritionalInfo.calories: 313 kcal per slice, roughly same as sandwitch

Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: Ancient Origins:\nThe concept of flatbread with toppings has ancient roots, with variations found in the cuisines of the Egyptians, Romans, and Greek
history.body: Modern Evolution:\nThe pizza we know today originated in Naples, Italy, between the 16th and mid-18th century. It was a dish for the poor, sold as street food before becoming a kitchen recipe
history.conclusion: Global Spread:\nAfter World War II, Allied troops stationed in Italy brought the love for pizza back to their home countries, contributing to its global popularity

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: In Italy, pizza is a source of national pride and is associated with social gatherings and special occassions.

name: Margherita Pizza
description: Margherita Pizza is a classic Neapolitan pizza that originated in Naples, Italy1. It’s characterized by its simplicity and fresh, high-quality ingredients2. The pizza is typically round with a raised edge and garnished with hand-crushed peeled tomatoes, mozzarella (buffalo mozzarella or fior di latte), fresh basil leaves, and extra virgin olive oil. The dough is traditionally made with flour, salt, and yeast
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.body: The Margherita Pizza was reportedly created in 1889 by the renowned pizza maker Raffaele Esposito of Pizzeria Brandi in Naples, Italy. He created a pizza resembling the colors of the Italian flag (red from tomato, white from mozzarella, and green from basil) in honor of the visiting Queen Margherita of Savoy

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: The colors of the Margherita pizza (red, white, and green) symbolize the colors of the Italian flag, representing the unity and patriotism of the Italian people.

name: Beef Burger
description: A beef burger is a popular type of sandwich that consists of one or more cooked patties of ground beef, usually seasoned with various spices, placed inside a sliced bread roll or bun. The patty may be pan fried, grilled, smoked or flame broiled.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The hamburger has spread from continent to continent, perhaps because it matches familiar elements in different culinary cultures
history.conclusion: This global culinary culture has been produced, in part, by the concept of selling processed food, first launched in the 1920s by the White Castle restaurant chain and its founder Edgar Waldo “Billy” Ingram and then refined by McDonald’s in the 1940s

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Burgers have become a symbol of freedom and independence in the United States. Burgers have transcended its origins to becoming one of the most beloved foods in modern society

name: Chicken Biryani
description: Chicken Biryani is a rich and aromatic dish that hails from the Indian subcontinent. It’s a one-pot dish made with a blend of basmati rice, chicken, and a mix of warm spices. It’s a dish that’s enjoyed by millions around the world and has countless regional variations, each with its own unique twist. Enjoying a plate of Chicken Biryani is truly an experience for the senses.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The dish is speculated to have developed in the royal kitchens of the Mughal Empire (1526–1857) and is a mix of the native spicy rice dishes of India and the Persian pilao. It is believed that the dish was brought to India by the Mughals
history.body: Today, biryani has countless regional variations, each with its own unique twist. It is one of the most popular dishes in South Asia and among the South Asian diaspora.
history.conclusion: It is also a widely sold street food and a popular celebratory dish3. Despite its origins, biryani has truly become a dish that is loved by millions around the world.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Biryani holds a special place in the cultural fabric of many countries, particularly in India, where it is enjoyed. It is often associated with celebrations, festivals, and special occasions, symbolizing abundance, hospitality, and togetherness. \nIt is also a beloved dish during religious festivals such as Eid, where families come together to share the joy and flavors of Biryani.

name: Pilau
description: In East Africa, Pilau is a traditional, fragrant rice dish made with many aromatic spices that add an amazing depth of flavor to the rice3. It can be made with either beef or chicken.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The history of Pilau can be traced back to ancient Persia, where it was known as “pilav.” It gained popularity during the Mughal Empire in India, where it was refined and incorporated into the local cuisine7. Over time, Pilau spread to other parts of Asia, Europe, and Africa, becoming a beloved dish in countless cultures.
history.conclusion: Over time, Pilau spread to other parts of Asia, Europe, and Africa, becoming a beloved dish in countless cultures.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Pilau holds great cultural significance, often served during festive occasions and celebrations, symbolizing abundance, prosperity, and togetherness.

name: Beef Biryani
description: Chicken Biryani is a rich and aromatic dish that hails from the Indian subcontinent. It’s a one-pot dish made with a blend of basmati rice, chicken, and a mix of warm spices. It’s a dish that’s enjoyed by millions around the world and has countless regional variations, each with its own unique twist. Enjoying a plate of Chicken Biryani is truly an experience for the senses.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The dish is speculated to have developed in the royal kitchens of the Mughal Empire (1526–1857) and is a mix of the native spicy rice dishes of India and the Persian pilao. It is believed that the dish was brought to India by the Mughals
history.body: Today, biryani has countless regional variations, each with its own unique twist. It is one of the most popular dishes in South Asia and among the South Asian diaspora.
history.conclusion: It is also a widely sold street food and a popular celebratory dish3. Despite its origins, biryani has truly become a dish that is loved by millions around the world.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Biryani holds a special place in the cultural fabric of many countries, particularly in India, where it is enjoyed. It is often associated with celebrations, festivals, and special occasions, symbolizing abundance, hospitality, and togetherness. \nIt is also a beloved dish during religious festivals such as Eid, where families come together to share the joy and flavors of Biryani.

name: Ugali
description: Ugali, also known as posho, nsima, and other names, is a type of cornmeal made from maize or corn flour in several countries in Africa. It is cooked in boiling water or milk until it reaches a stiff or firm dough-like consistency. This dish is a Tanzanian favorite, traditionally served for lunch, and dinner. It is often served with a variety of dishes such as stews, vegetables, and meats.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The history of Ugali traces back to the Bantu people who introduced maize to Africa around 500-1000 AD.
history.conclusion: Portuguese traders introduced maize to the Kenyan coastal region in the 19th Century. Over time, this grain became an integral part of Kenyan agriculture and diet.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Ugali is much more than just a dish; it is a symbol of tradition, community, and sustenance in African culture. Its humble yet significant presence on the dining tables of African households reflects the enduring connection between food and identity.

name: Wali
description: A type of rice dish in East Africa, particularly in Swahili-speaking regions
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.body: Wali as a rice dish has been a staple in East African cuisine for centuries.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: A dish that is integral to the cultural identity of its speakers in East Africa.

pairings.pairingDish: Kuku Choma (Grilled Chicken marinated in a splice blend)

name: Supu
description: The term “Supu” is often used to refer to soup in Swahili-speaking regions. A traditional dish often made with a variety of ingredients which can include meat (such as beef, chicken, or fish) and a variety of vegetables. A specific version of Supu, known as Supu Viazi, includes ingredients like coconut milk, potatoes, peppers, onions, and tomatoes. This soup is thickened with coconut milk, giving it a lovely, tropical flare. //nSupu can be served as a standalone meal or paired with other dishes. In some cultures, it is common to serve Supu with rice or bread(chapati & mandazi)
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.body: Supu is a dish that has been a part of Swahili culinary traditions for a long time, evolving with the ingredients available in different regions and periods.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: A dish that is integral to the cultural identity of its speakers in East Africa.

name: Donuts
description: Donuts, also known as doughnuts, are a type of pastry made from leavened fried dough.  Donuts are usually deep-fried from a flour dough, and various toppings and flavors are used for different types, such as sugar, chocolate, or maple glazing. The two most common types are the ring donut and the filled donut, which is injected with fruit preserves, cream, custard, or other sweet fillings.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The history of Donuts can be traced back to ancient times, where the concept of fried dough was prevalent in various cultures around the world.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Donuts have transcended their role as just a food item and have become entrenched in American pop culture.

name: Chapati
description: Chapati, also known as roti, is an unleavened flatbread originating from the Indian subcontinent. It is made from whole wheat flour, water, and optionally salt and oil. The dough is usually baked on a griddle.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: Chapati originated in the Indus valley civilization and later spread to Southeast and Central Asia, East Africa, and the Caribbean
history.conclusion: Some historical accounts claim that chapati originated in East Africa and was later brought to the Indian subcontinent by travelers or merchants.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Chapati is much more than just a dish; it is a symbol of tradition, community, and sustenance in many cultures.

name: Maandazi
description: Maandazi, also known as Mandazi, is a type of fried bread that originated on the Swahili Coast1. It’s a slightly sweet snack that you can find in most East African countries, especially along the Swahili coasts of Kenya and Tanzania. It’s made from easy-to-obtain ingredients such as cardamom, flour, vanilla, and coconut. Maandazi is often made triangular in shape, similar to samosas, but can also be shaped as circles or ovals.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The history of Maandazi can be traced back to more than 4 centuries ago, in the small villages of East Africa where there was no bread available to residents for breakfast
history.body: The women of these small villages had to find a solution and collectively elaborated their own recipes of these fried buns.
history.conclusion: The Maandazi traveled to the Sultanate of Oman, a country in the Middle East, south of the Arabian Peninsula.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Maandazi holds great cultural significance in East Africa as it symbolizes unity and celebration. People often prepare and serve Maandazi

name: Cupcakes
description: Maandazi, also known as Mandazi, is a type of fried bread that originated on the Swahili Coast1. It’s a slightly sweet snack that you can find in most East African countries, especially along the Swahili coasts of Kenya and Tanzania. It’s made from easy-to-obtain ingredients such as cardamom, flour, vanilla, and coconut. Maandazi is often made triangular in shape, similar to samosas, but can also be shaped as circles or ovals.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The earliest extant description of what is now often called a cupcake was in 1796, when a recipe for “a light cake to bake in small cups” was written in American Cookery by Amelia Simmons

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Today, cupcakes have become a symbol of celebration and joy. They are often used to mark special occasions such as birthdays, weddings, and baby showers. In addition to their popularity as a dessert, cupcakes have also become a cultural icon, with numerous TV shows, movies, and books featuring them prominently

name: Muffins
description: Maandazi, also known as Mandazi, is a type of fried bread that originated on the Swahili Coast1. It’s a slightly sweet snack that you can find in most East African countries, especially along the Swahili coasts of Kenya and Tanzania. It’s made from easy-to-obtain ingredients such as cardamom, flour, vanilla, and coconut. Maandazi is often made triangular in shape, similar to samosas, but can also be shaped as circles or ovals.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The earliest known reference to muffins dates back to the 14th century, when English monks wrote about a small cake-like bread called ‘mofyns’. However, it is unclear whether these mofyns were actually muffins, or if they more closely resembled modern scones
history.body: The term muffin originally referred to a type of bread in Europe, particularly in England. Muffins were a common street food, sold door to door by the “muffin men”. These early versions were more bread-like and less sweet than the muffins we know today.
history.conclusion: Muffins made their way to America with the first settlers9. They were initially similar to British muffins but began to evolve as settlers adapted to new ingredients and cooking methods.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: They are a quintessential part of breakfast and brunch menus, cherished for their convenience and versatility. In England, muffins became synonymous with tea time, and they were often enjoyed with butter and jam. \nIn the United States, muffins became a staple in American households, especially during the pioneer era, where they were made with ingredients readily available such as cornmeal or wheat flour. \nToday, muffins have become a symbol of celebration and joy. They are often used to mark special occasions such as birthdays, weddings, and baby showers.

name: Sambusa
description: Sambusa, also known as samosa, is a popular savory snack that originated in the Middle East and South Asia. It is a triangular-shaped pastry filled with a delicious mixture of meat, vegetables, and spices. Sambusa is commonly served as an appetizer or snack at parties, gatherings, and special occasions.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The history of sambusa dates back to the 9th century, where it was believed to have been introduced to the Middle East by traders from Central Asia.
history.body: Over time, sambusa spread to South Asia and Africa, where it became a popular street food and snack.
history.conclusion: The South Asian samosa is believed to be derived from a medieval precursor from the Middle East.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Sambusa has a rich cultural significance in various regions. In East Africa, sambusa is a staple at celebrations, family gatherings, and during the holy month of Ramadan. They are often enjoyed with a cup of chai (tea) and symbolize unity and sharing among communities

name: Chipsi Kavu
description: Chipsi Kavu, is a popular street food in Tanzania. The term “Kavu” in Swahili translates to “dry”, which implies that these are just plain, dry fries without any additional ingredients or toppings.

nutritionalInfo.calories: 365 kcal for a medium sized portion

Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.body: Chipsi Kavu is a street meal in Tanzania comprised of French fries and eggs3. From Dodoma city to Dar city, it can be found in every single corner of the Eastern African nation. The dish is heavily influenced by Indian and Arabic cuisine.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Chipsi Mayai is a staple of Tanzanian street food

name: Chipsi Mayai
description: Chipsi Mayai is a popular street food in Tanzania. The name is derived from Swahili, where “Chipsi” means “French fries” and “Mayai” means “eggs”. Think of it as omlet with fries mixed in

nutritionalInfo.calories: 350 kcal for a medium sized portion

Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.body: Chips Mayai, also known as Zege, is a popular Tanzanian street food that was invented in the streets of Dar es Salaam2. It is available in all regions of Tanzania, from the most remote villages to large towns.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Chips Mayai is not just a delicious dish; it also holds cultural significance in Tanzania. It’s a comfort food that’s cherished by people of all ages and backgrounds. Whether you’re enjoying it from a street vendor or making it at home, Chips Mayai is a symbol of the rich culinary diversity found in Tanzanian cuisine.

name: Shawarma
description: Shawarma is a popular Middle Eastern dish that originated in the Levant region of the Arab world during the Ottoman Empire. It consists of meat that is cut into thin slices, stacked in an inverted cone, and roasted on a slow-turning vertical spit. Traditionally made with lamb or mutton, it may also be made with chicken, turkey, beef, or veal. The surface of the rotisserie meat is routinely shaved off once it cooks and is ready to be served. Shawarma is a popular street food throughout the Arab world and the Greater Middle East.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.intro: The Shawarma technique—grilling a vertical stack of meat slices and cutting it off as it cooks—first appeared in the Ottoman Empire in the 19th century in the form of döner kebab.
history.body: This method was adopted in neighboring countries: in Syria, Lebanon, and Jordan it came to be known in Arabic as Shawarma, a loanword from the Turkish çevirme, or “turn,” and in Greece as gyro, with the same meaning.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Shawarma is a type of dish that so many cultures originating from the Middle East have enjoyed together for countless years, and binds people together because of the memories attached to those flavors.

name: Nyama Choma
description: Nyama Choma is a traditional dish from East Africa, particularly popular in Kenya and Tanzania. The term “Nyama Choma” translates to “barbecued meat” in Swahili. It typically consists of goat or beef meat and sometimes chicken meat that is marinated, then slow-roasted on a grill.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.body: Nyama Choma’s origins can be traced back to the traditional cooking methods of the Maasai people, a nomadic tribe found in Kenya and Tanzania. As pastoralists, they relied heavily on livestock for sustenance, and grilling meat became a common practice.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: It’s a symbol of hospitality and friendship, often shared among friends and family during celebrations and gatherings

name: Kitimoto
description: Kitimoto is a traditional dish from Tanzania, particularly popular in Dar es Salaam.  It typically consists of pork that is marinated, then slow-roasted on a grill1. The meat is anointed with a number of spices including soy sauce, vinegar, pepper, and ginger, and placed on a hot grill for comfortable slow cooking or tossed in hot oil1.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Kitimoto is deeply ingrained in Tanzanian culture and is considered a national delicacy. It is an important part of Tanzanian cuisine and social gatherings, representing a sense of community, celebration, and tradition

pairings.pairingDish: Ndizi Choma (Roast Plantains with vegetable salad)

name: Vitumbua
description: Vitumbua is a traditional dish from East Africa, particularly popular in Tanzania and other Swahili-speaking regions. It’s a type of rice pancake often enjoyed as a breakfast or snack. These bite-sized pancakes are made from a fermented batter of ground rice and coconut milk. They are known for their slight exterior crust and a fluffy, melt-in-your-mouth interior.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.body: This dish has been a part of East African culinary traditions for a long time, evolving with the ingredients available in different regions and periods.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Vitumbua is a popular Tanzanian street food and is also popular in some other East African. A common breakfast option in East Africa

These bite-sized pancakes are made from a fermented batter of ground rice and coconut milk. They are known for their slight exterior crust and a fluffy, melt-in-your-mouth interior.
Popularity: based on number or times ordered

history.body: This dish has been a part of East African culinary traditions for a long time, evolving with the ingredients available in different regions and periods.

SpecialNotes.culturalMerit: Vitumbua is a popular Tanzanian street food and is also popular in some other East African. A common breakfast option in East Africa
